item.title: Ethereum Application Binary Interface (ABI) in Go
item.description:
About this post

The Application Binary Interface (ABI) is a standarised way to interact with a contract in an Ethereum network. The ABI is typically implemented in JSON format and used in conjunction with web3.js Javascript libraries to interact with a deployed solidity contract. I’ll briefly cover this technique here.

In this post, I’ll present an alternative approach using Go based ABI in lieu of JSON/web3.js combination. For the purpose of illustration, I’ll be using a deployed contract, also referred to as a token, named Tronix on Ethereum Mainnet. I’ll be demonstrating the process of obtaining a balance of the token.

It is NOT the purpose of this post to avocate the use of Go instead of JSON/wbe3.js. The intention here is to demonstrate, if you choose to use Go, the steps involved. I’ll leave the choice of using Go over JSON/web3.js or vice-versa to you to decide.

item.title: Go and Rust array and slice -- a comparison
item.description:
About this post

In this post, I’ll examine the concept of array and slice from the perspective of Go and Rust.

Go array and slice

An array in Go is an ordered collection of elements. Not unlike Rust as you will see.

You simply declare an array this way:

A slice is a data type that gives you, as the name suggest, a slice of an underlying array.

For example, when you declare a slice in this manner:

The slice in this case is a type containing a reference to the first elements of an array. The slice also contains attributes indicating the number of elements (i.e. len) and the capacity (i.e. cap) of the array. Both len and cap will have the same value. Length denotes the number of elements that slice it is able to view in the array from the initial reference position. Cap refers to the maximum size of the array.

We could also use slice to “expand” the capacity of the array by this command:

In this context we are not really expanding the initial array but simply create a new array with double the capacity of the initial array. The elements of the old array copied to the new one with an extra element appended. We can see the relationship between a slice and its array is shown in Figure 1.

If we declared a slice this way:

This tells the slice to view elements of the array starting from index 1 and before index 2. The slice will have reference to the second element of the array. The slice would only hava a len for 1. This means if you were to range over the slice, you will only get the second element of the array. However, from the perspective of the slice, the value 1 in the array is recorded as index 0 in the slice as opposed to index 1 in the array.

There are alternative approach to declaring a slice. One approach is to use the command make:

This will create a slice with an underlying array of length 4 and capcity 4, where the array is initialised with values 0.

Another approach is to declare a slice and array field with elements [1,2,3,4] as shown below:

The choice approach to declare a slice and array has an impact on performance. You will need to judge which approach based on your use case.

Rust array and slice

An array in Rust is declared this way:

We can declare a slice this way:

In the case of rust, slice is a variable of a slice type with a length attribute. slice is a reference to an array, where pointer in the slice points to the second element of array. The len attribute will have a value of 1.

Figure 2 illustrate the relationship between a slice and an array.

My observations

In the case of Go, a slice is all you need to use as an index collection type for most cases and you can treat it much like an expandable array. You can easily iterate through a slice to obtain elements of its underlying array or simply restrict you slice to a subset of array and iterate through that.

Rust slices support limited operations. There is no equivalent to Go’s append operation to expand its underlying array or a cap to determine the length of the underlying array. There indirect ways of getting the same effect as Go slice. There are, however, higher order data types like vector that you could use.

item.title: Go and Rust workspace and modules -- a comparison
item.description:
About this post

It is rare, if ever, for any major project to involve only a single source file. So when you start a major software project, it is important to do so on the right foundation. A software project that is able to scale easily is one where the project is organised around modules where each module address a separate concern.

In this post, I am going to compare Go and Rust approach to organising projects for scaling. I’ll demonstrate, using comparable file structures, ways to organise multiple modules in a single Github repository. I’ll use the term workspace in place of the term repository to coincide with Rust terminology.

It is beyond the scope of this post to discuss in details Go and Rust concepts of modules and packages. Please refer to the respective language documentation for details. This blog will focus specifically on how to organise folders and files in a workspace such that Go and Rust projects are similar in layout for comparison.

Go workspace

It is worth noting that Go projects do not have a formal equivalence of a workspace. However, you can organise multiple Go modules around a single repository to achieve the similar effect as Rust’s workspace. The following layout is an example of a Go multiple-modules workspace.

In this layout, myapp is a Go module for generating executables. Whereas mylib is a Go module serving as an public sharable library. By convention, because mylib is a shareable module, it has name to that can be located via a valid url. In the case of myapp which is not meant to share code with external projects, a simple one word name will suffice.

Please refer to a working layout in my Github repo for detail.

Rust workspace

The equivalent layout in Rust is as follows:

Similar to the Go layout, you have myapp module responsible for generating an executable and mylib module responsible for generating libraries that you can share locally or via a package repository.

Please refer to a working layout in my Github repo for detail.

My observations

The main difference between a Go and a Rust workspace is a top level (i.e. at the workspace root) Cargo.toml package manager for latter. A Go workspace does not have a top level package manager. So there is no direct relationship between its modules. In other words, mylib will not be visible to myapp until the former has been pushed to the source repository and tag for Go workspace. So you can’t make changes to mylib and for myapp to take effect at code time. In this respect, organising multiple Go modules in a single workspace may not offer much efficiency co-ordinating across modules. So the layout as presented in this post is very much a matter of personal choice.

The other difference is in the tools. Rust has a package management tool known as Cargo, to create the layout mentioned above and also co-ordinate dependencies between the modules during the build process. Go tools do not have feature to create “standard” layout like Cargo. Go tools (i.e. go install and go mod) manages dependencies but it is done in conjunction with source code repositories hosting the Go codes. How well the flexibity afford by Go project layout and the fix layout afforded by Rust/Cargo in the context of refactoring, is a topic I will explore in future post.

item.title: Manipulating Docker containers via Go -- working with images
item.description:
About this post

In this post, I’ll show you ways to manipulate docker operations directly from your Go codes as an alternative to using Docker cli and docker-compose script.

It is beyond the scope of this post to discuss in detail Docker’s architecture. Refer to the official Docker documentation for detail.

For the purpose of this post, Docker is a client-server application where the server is running as a daemon in your platform (Linux, macOS and Windows).

In essence, when you work with your Go code (i.e. the client) to interact with Docker you are basically interacting with Docker server via sockets.

There are two ways you can get your Go code to interact with Docker server. One approach is to use Docker’s Go SDK. The other approach is to use the RESTFul API. I’ll show you how it is done using the two approaches specifically when it comes to pulling Docker images from Docker registry.

Next, connect your client to the Docker API. The API to pull images is in the endpoint /images/create. Yes, pull and create images have the same endpoint. So it can be confusing.

Last words

As you can see the steps involved in creating a Go base client using SDK and API is fairly straightforward.

However, you might be asking why not just execute shell commands via Docker’s cli with Docker Compose script. Of course, you could. What I have presented here are illustrations of alternative ways to manipulate docker from Go code. It is for you to find a use case appropriate for your project. For example, you might find it useful to create native apps manipulating a few Docker containers where you might not need platforms as complex as Kubernetes to manipulate containers.

In this post I have covered one operation, which is to pull an image. The steps involved in manipulating other operations is broadly the same except for details such as SDK arguments or API parameters settings. I’ll cover those and other Docker components in future posts.

item.title: Go and Rust package management -- my initial observations
item.description:
About this post

In this post, I’ll share my research of package management for Go and Rust.

Go package management

I won’t go into detail of how Go manage dependencies, you can find it in the official blog.

You can augment you knowledge of Go packagement by reading this blogs Evaluating Go’s Package Management and Module Systems by Ayooluwa Isaiah.

It is also worth noting that Go does not enforce the way you organise your project layout. I highly recommend you use organise your project along the lines of the Standard Go Project Layout. I am sure some of you would argue that the title of the layout does not imply they layout as a “standard”. Yes, I agree with you on that point but having followed the “standard”, I have found it a very good layout. In particular it helps to separate application code from support codes and easy for anyone working on the project to understand the intention behind the codes.

Rust package management

I am a Rust newbie and still learning to code with Rust. As far as I can tell, Rust uses a package management tool call Cargo. For further details, please refer to this blog Getting started with the Rust package manager, Cargo.

I don’t have a sense if there is a standard project layout but based on the layout generated by Cargo, it appears to be similar to Java’s maven project structure namely, the use of src and target. Beyond that I can’t comment.

My observations

As a newbie to Rust, all I would say about Rust/Cargo project layout seemed restrictive for me. But it maybe because I have not mastered the art of using Cargo fully, With the Go standard project layout, it allows me to organised my Go support code (some written in Go itself, Docker scripts, etc) cleanly and separate from the application code.
